704107f-a.text:
Emmons Ave., south side, opposite Sheepshead Bay Road. his eating establishment known as "Domenick's Hotel" in 1924 and as Huismaig' Eotel in
1890 was demolished in 1934.
January 1924.
Eugene L. Armbruster Collection.
704107f-a.folder: Emmons Avenue & Sheepshead Bay Road, Brooklyn, NY
704107f-a.original_title: Brooklyn: Emmons Avenue - Sheepshead Bay Road

704102f-b.text:
Emmons Avenue, east from Sheepshead Bay Road, showing the piers, fishing boats and restaurants lining the Sheepshead Bay waterfront. On the extreme right is Shore Boulevard, at Manhattan Beach. Views 2, 3, and 4 show the new bulkhead, marked off by the line of piles. All the old frame structure and piers on the water's edge will be razed and the avenue widened another twenty feet by the W. P. A. View 4 is in a westerly direction and shows, in the background, the Bayview Apartments.
View 1: April 5, 134
View 2,3,4: June 27, 1934
Works Progess Administration
Five Boroughs Project

704105f-a.text:
Emmons Ave., south side, looking east from Sheepshead Bay Road. These shacks once the pride of Sheepshead Bay, were condemned by the City of New York, to make way for the new Emmons Ave., and Promenade.
July 8, 1933.
P. L. Sperr.
704105f-a.folder: Emmons Avenue & Sheepshead Bay Road, Brooklyn, NY
704105f-a.original_title: Brooklyn: Emmons Avenue - Sheepshead Bay Road

704104f-c.text:
Emmons Avenue, east from Sheepshead Bay Road, showing the W. P. A. widening the avenue, as part of tho City's new Belt Parkway system, which will gird the five boroughs. The thoroughfare was widened about twenty feet, which necesstated the filling in of part of Sheepshead Bay, the razing of old piers and boat houses, and the construction of a new bulkhead. The building -- in Spanish architecture -- seen on the left in the four views, is the Lundy Brothers Restaurant.
Viow 1: September 12, 1935
Viows 2,3: Septomber 26, 1935
View 4: Novomber 18, 1936
Works Progress Administration
Five Boroughs Project

704106f-a.text:
(1)
Emmons Ave., north side, between Sheepshead Bay Road and East 19th Street. I the right background, is the New Lundy Restaurant, erected
in 1934.
August 1, 1935.
P. L. Sperr.
NO REE ODUCTIONS.  Negiwe t~E641
(2)
The same, showing only 1825-1827, at the N.W. corner of East 19th Street.
July 9, 1936.
P. L. Sperr.
(3)
Bhowihd Nos. 1807-1819 at the N.E. corner of Sheepshead Bay Road. The building with the conical roof once housed the only carousel, and
was the first "movie", in the Sheepshead Bay area.
July 9, 1936.
P. L. Sperr.

704100f-b.text:
Emmons Avenue, west from near Sheepshead Bay Road, showing W. P. A. men widening the thoroughfare, this being part of the city's new Belt Parkway system,  which girds New York's five boroughs. View 2 is from near E. 15th Street, and shows the B. M. T. Brighton Beach Subway in the background.

October 27, 1936
Views 1,2

Works Progress Administration
Five Boroughs Project

704101f-a.text:
Emmons Avenue, west from near Sheepshead Bay Road, showing the thoroughfare being widened and a new bulkhead erected by the W. P. A. Many old piers and boathhouses were razed and part of Sheepshead Bay filled in when the avenue was widened, as part of the city's Belt Parkway
highway system.
View 1: February 28, 1936
View 2: June 17, 1936
Works Progress Administration
Five Bouroughs Project
